content.description: Arete left of Lone Wolf from a sit.  Same Boulder, in the corridor. Start with your left hand on the arete and right with a pinchy edge.  You will probably finish with the same mantle as Lone Wolf.  Technical slab compression climbing.
From a sit on the left side of the arete, climb it.
content.location: On the Lone Wolf Boulder, look at that problem for directions.  Directly below the Larry Collins bench.

content.description: Super obvious arete climb as you enter the corridor proper. Start sitting with a good jug shelf and a left hand undercling jug.  Sequence up to a good break and then up even higher. Top out is easy
content.location: First route encountered after the Howling as you come into the main corridor. Just left of Canis Lupus

content.description: From good holds right of the arete, climb to a jug, then commit to an airy sequence that uses the arete, high off the ground, to easing, but delicate and serious climbing up high.  A proud and incredible line.
content.protection: Pads and spotters. More pads are better.
content.location: Straight below the Larry Collins bench.  Just north on the same cliff band as Lone Wolf.

content.description: Start sitting on a ledge, with an inverted diamond pinch for the left hand and punchy edge for the right. Move left, pull through a couple cruxy moves, then wrap left around the arete and up.  The top is pretty easy but a fall might be weird with a boulder behind you.
content.location: Below the Larry Collins bench.  Not far.  Easiest to access by walking just south of the bench, leaving the trail, and traversing back north.  Just north of The Howling.

content.description: From a jug, climb the pillar on good holds for the most part.  There is a long reach at the top.  Take care, a fall near the top could be very bad.
content.protection: Pads, maybe a spotter and a steady head.
content.location: Just past the Larry Collins bench on the left.  Very close to the trail.

content.description:
Canis Lupus - The Wolf

 Sit start with left hand in a triangle ledge and right in small crimp. Climb the face up to a good horizontal break. Find small holds and high feet to an airy mantle finish. This stays consistent at the grade and isnt over until you're on top.

 Channel your inner wolf and send those final moves !
content.location: Just right of timberwolf arete as you first enter the main corridor. Climb the face without using the arete holds.

content.description: This thin and slabby climb follows the face up the canine shaped boulder. From a stand or sit work your way to a good ledge. Balance, mantle, crimp, or will yourself up to a high hold and topout.Left blocky holds and right arete are both offThe positive crimps and low angle make this a satisfying puzzle to solve. Must do for this area!
content.location: Right in the center of the corridor is a slabby boulder that slightly resembles a wolf's canine. This route goes up the center. Boulder is just left of the Lone Wolf arete

content.description: Obvious blocky jug line left of the Canine. Follow the cracks and blocks up to the top
content.location: Left side of the canine boulder, in between Canis Lupus and Lone Wolf. An easy 5th class downclimb is just to the left of this route and can be used for most of the boulders near there

content.description:
Bouldering along the top of the West Bluff!

The Larry Collins Bench on the West Bluff is a good reference point.  Most things here aren’t far of the trail, the access is good and fairly convenient.  The Larry Collins bench is probably a quarter mile or so north of Prospect Point for reference.
